docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic presidential contender John Edwards, who curtailed his Iowa trip on Tuesday to be with his wife, Elizabeth, for her post-cancer medical appointments this week, announced tonight that they would be holding a news conference tomorrow at noon in Chapel Hill.

headline.main: Edwards Curtails Campaign Trip to Be With Wife

docs.abstract: John Edwards's wife went through two medical appointments this week, following her bout with breast cancer.
docs.snippet: John Edwards's wife went through two medical appointments this week, following her bout with breast cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Subject to final approval, the decision would make Massachusetts the first state to establish standards that apply to every resident and every insurer.

headline.main: Massachusetts Sets Benefits in Universal Health Care Plan
headline.print_headline: Massachusetts Sets Benefits in Universal Health Care Plan

docs.snippet: Subject to final approval, the decision would make Massachusetts the first state to establish standards that apply to every resident and every insurer.

docs.lead_paragraph: The figures suggest that civil union licenses have been far less popular in New Jersey than when they were introduced in Vermont in 2000 and in Connecticut in 2005.

headline.main: Couples Not Rushing to Civil Unions in New Jersey
headline.sub: Numbers Fewer Than Elsewhere; Some Insist on Full Marriage;

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit may have ruled that it is not discriminatory for Union Pacific to exclude contraceptive coverage in its health plan, it is clearly fiscally irresponsible (''Court Says Health Coverage May Bar Birth-Control Pills,'' news article, March 17).
docs.abstract: Letter from James Trussell, director of Princeton University's Office of Population Research, and Wayne Shields, president and chief executive of Assn of Reproductive Health Professionals, argue that Union Pacific's exclusion of contraceptive coverage in its health plan may not be discriminatory, but it is fiscally irresponsible (March 17 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Records show 229 same-sex couples have applied for civil union licenses since Feb. 19, when they became legal.

headline.main: No Rush to Get Civil Unions in New Jersey
headline.print_headline: No Rush to Get Civil Unions in New Jersey, Early Numbers Show

docs.snippet: Records show 229 same-sex couples have applied for civil union licenses since Feb. 19, when they became legal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients who have trouble paying their medical bills do significantly worse in the year after heart attacks than patients under less financial pressure, a new study finds.

headline.main: Money: Financial Troubles Can Affect the Heart
headline.print_headline: Financial Troubles Can Affect the Heart

docs.snippet: Patients who have trouble paying their medical bills do significantly worse in the year after heart attacks than patients under less financial pressure, a new study finds.

docs.lead_paragraph: MISSING MEDICARE TAXES Federal investigators say thousands of doctors and other health professionals participating in Medicare are late in paying more than $1 billion in federal income and payroll taxes. [A1.] QUESTIONS FOR THE I.R.S. The head of the Internal Revenue Service, Mark W. Everson, below, is expected to testify today before members of the House Ways and Means Committee after agency auditors complained that they were forced to close corporate tax cases prematurely, allowing billions in taxes to go unpaid. [C1.] WAL-MART'S VIEW OF FIRINGS Wal-Mart explains why it fired two executives placing its lucrative advertising account and the agency that was initially awarded the business. The explanation contradicts statements by the two executives. [C1.] A VISIT FROM A GIANT JET The largest passenger plane in the world, the Airbus 380, begins a United States tour by stopping at Kennedy International Airport. [C1.] AND A RIDE ON A GIANT JET For one of the Airbus 380s visiting the United States, the flight was a dress rehearsal. On the Road: Joe Sharkey. [C9.] BIG OIL LOVES ANGOLA Angola, a corrupt, underdeveloped and war-scarred country, is now the world's fastest-growing oil exporter and the newest darling of the worldwide oil industry. [C1.] NO ENRON CLASS-ACTION SUIT A federal appeals court says a class-action lawsuit against investment banks for their alleged role in the accounting scandal cannot proceed. [C1.] PET FOOD DEATHS Seven cats and dogs died in a taste test last month by the Canadian manufacturer of more than 60 million cans of pet food that have been recalled, the Food and Drug Administration says. [A12.] FOUL PLAY? Democrats in Congress have released documents showing government climate reports were edited to play up uncertainty or play down evidence of a human role in global warming. [A12.] MYSPACE RESTRICTIONS MySpace, the Web's largest social network, is gradually imposing limits on the software tools that users can embed in their pages. Some users are not happy about it. [C3.] A FATHER OF FORTRAN DIES John W. Backus, who assembled and led the I.B.M. team that created the Fortran programming language, has died. [B7.] STATE FARM'S PLAN State Farm insurance says it will work through regulators in Mississippi, speeding the flow of money to storm victims -- but without a federal court's protections. [C4.] CONRAD BLACK'S TRIAL IS DELAYED The trial in federal court in Chicago of Conrad M. Black and three former associates, accused of looting the newspaper company Hollinger International, was delayed after some questions were raised about financial settlements in the case made by a chief witness, F. David Radler. [C3.] NO PARACHUTE In an effort to return money to employees who took wage cuts and to provide workers with an incentives as it exits bankruptcy, Delta will not reward its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, with stock, compensation or severance when he leaves the company. [C3.] SERVICEMASTER ACCEPTS BID ServiceMaster, the owner of TruGreen ChemLawn and Terminix pest control, said yesterday that it had accepted a $4.7 billion takeover bid from a group led by the private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. The buyout firm offered to pay more than $15.62 a share and will assume about $800 million in debt. [C2.] LOWER RATING FOR TUNDRA PICKUP Toyota's Tundra pickup truck did not achieve the five-star rating in head-on crash tests given to all full-size pickups made by Detroit. [C3.] BEER AD ON THE WEB In a new promotion to begin in mid-April, the Silver Bullet train used in advertising by Coors Light will race across video screens at various Web sites frequented by males 21 to 34. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C6.] ONLINE THE EXECUTIVE PAY PACKAGE More coverage of executive pay packages and interactive features are in a special section on executive pay at nytimes.com/business. DEALBOOK Time Warner says AOL is a core asset, but some on Wall Street think the Internet business would be worth much more to someone else. An up-to-the-minute financial report on mergers and acquisitions is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. EGL INC., THE PARENT of Eagle Global Logistics, said that it had agreed to be acquired by its chairman and chief executive, James R. Crane, along with two private equity firms in a deal valued at about $1.7 billion. (DOW JONES/AP) PITNEY BOWES INC., which makes postage meters and mailing equipment, announced that its president, Murray D. Martin, would become chief executive and join the board. (AP) QUANTA SERVICES INC., a builder of energy and telecommunications networks based in Houston, said that it would buy InfraSource Services Inc. for $1.26 billion. (REUTERS) HERCULES OFFSHORE, the oil and gas drilling rig company, said it had agreed to buy a larger rival, Todco, for $2.3 billion in cash and stock, giving it a stronger position in the Gulf of Mexico. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: Exaggerated fears that illegal immigrants are fraudulently receiving Medicaid health benefits have led to a crackdown that is preventing American citizens from obtaining legitimate coverage. Congress needs to fix this injustice.
docs.snippet: Exaggerated fears that illegal immigrants are fraudulently receiving Medicaid health benefits have led to a crackdown that is preventing American citizens from obtaining legitimate coverage. Congress needs to fix this injustice.
